key_points: The Ever Given container ship was freed from the Suez Canal today, five days after becoming lodged.
It blocked the Suez Canal since March 23, causing a massive traffic jam of over 360 ships.
The blockage was a significant disruption, potentially costing billions in delayed shipments.
Dredgers and tugboats, aided by a spring tide from a full moon, managed to free the ship.
The Ever Given is now being towed to the Great Bitter Lake for inspection.
Originally, high winds during a sandstorm were blamed, but technical or human errors are also being investigated.
The blockage forced some ships to take a longer route around Africa, raising concerns about piracy.
The Suez Canal is a critical maritime link, and the blockage threatened significant economic impacts worldwide.
Egypt operates the Suez Canal, which contributed $5.6 billion to its revenue in 2020.
The Ever Given, operated by Evergreen Marine of Taiwan, is a Panama-flagged ship built in 2018.
